|work= This Is My Next |date= 09 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |url= http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/07/samsung-and-google-postpone-ice-cream-sandwich-and-galaxy-nexus/ |publisher=Engadget |date=2011-10-7 |title=Samsung and Google postpone Ice Cream Sandwich and Galaxy Nexus}}</ref> eventually taking place on 19 October in Hong Kong.<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RX4btquQzUE</ref> Android Head of Engineering, Mike Claren, called it the companyâs "most ambitious release to date."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fonehome.co.uk/2011/05/17/android-ice-cream-sandwich-vs-honeycomb/ |title=Android Ice Cream Sandwich vs HoneyComb |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=17 May 2011}}</ref> Features include facial recognition and new [[API]]s to reduce development fragmentation.<ref>{{Citation |url= http://gizmodo.com/5800358/what-is-androids-ice-cream-sandwich |publisher=Gizmodo |title=What is Androidâs Ice cream sandwich}}</ref> To date, there is evidence of:
+
As officially announced during the 2011 [[Google I/O]], the 4.x<ref>{{Citation | publisher = Android community | url = http://cdn.androidcommunity.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/ics6.jpg | format = [[JPEG]] | type = Picture | title = ICS6 | date = 2011â10}}.</ref> version of Android is called ''Ice Cream Sandwich'',<ref name="i/o 2011 stats">{{cite web |url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/05/android-momentum-mobile-and-more-at.html |title=Android: momentum, mobile and more at Google I/O |first= Hugo |last=Barra |work=The Official Google Blog |date=10 May 2011|accessdate=10 May 2011}}</ref> a combination of Gingerbread and Honeycomb into a "cohesive whole".<ref name="icecream-sandwich">{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EYxP5bLY5gI#t=13m27s |title=Eric Schmidt, Google Chairman & CEO Keynote |publisher= [[GSMA]] |work=[[Mobile World Congress]] |date=15 February 2011}}</ref> An event based around the [[Galaxy Nexus]] and Ice Cream Sandwich was on 19 October, 2011 in Hong Kong.<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RX4btquQzUE</ref> Android Head of Engineering, Mike Claren, called it the companyâs "most ambitious release to date."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fonehome.co.uk/2011/05/17/android-ice-cream-sandwich-vs-honeycomb/ |title=Android Ice Cream Sandwich vs HoneyComb |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=17 May 2011}}</ref> Features include facial recognition and new [[API]]s to reduce development fragmentation.<ref>{{Citation |url= http://gizmodo.com/5800358/what-is-androids-ice-cream-sandwich |publisher=Gizmodo |title=What is Androidâs Ice cream sandwich}}</ref> To date, there is evidence of:
* the unification of phone and tablet UIs and APIs<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mobot.net/evidence-grows-suggest-android-ics-android-40-30654 |publisher=Mobot |title=Evidence grows, suggests Android ICS}}.</ref>
* the unification of phone and tablet UIs and APIs<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mobot.net/evidence-grows-suggest-android-ics-android-40-30654 |publisher=Mobot |title=Evidence grows, suggests Android ICS}}.</ref>
